title: List of topics characterized as pseudoscience - Wikipedia
cleaned_text: List of topics characterized as pseudoscience |Part of a series on| [subseries](/wiki/Category:Philosophy_and_thinking_sidebar_templates)on [philosophy](/wiki/Philosophy). In order to explore related topics, please visit [navigation](/wiki/Template:Philosophy_of_science). This is a list of topics that have, either currently or in the past, been characterized as [pseudoscience](/wiki/Pseudoscience) by academics or researchers. Detailed discussion of these topics may be found on their main pages. These characterizations were made in the context of educating the public about questionable or potentially fraudulent or dangerous claims and practices—efforts to define the nature of [science](/wiki/Science), or humorous parodies of poor scientific reasoning. Criticism of pseudoscience, generally by the [scientific community](/wiki/Scientific_community) or [skeptical](/wiki/Scientific_skepticism) organizations, involves critiques of the [logical](/wiki/Logic), [methodological](/wiki/Scientific_method), or [rhetorical](/wiki/Rhetoric) bases of the topic in question. [[1]](#cite_note-Pollak2002-1) Though some of the listed topics continue to be investigated scientifically, others were only subject to scientific research in the past and today are considered refuted, but resurrected in a pseudoscientific fashion. Other ideas presented here are entirely non-scientific, but have in one way or another impinged on scientific domains or practices. Many adherents or practitioners of the topics listed here dispute their characterization as pseudoscience. Each section here summarizes the alleged pseudoscientific aspects of that topic. Physical sciences Astronomy and space sciences [2012 phenomenon](/wiki/2012_phenomenon)- a range of [eschatological](/wiki/Eschatology) [beliefs](/wiki/Belief)that cataclysmic or otherwise transformative events would occur on or around 21 December 2012. This date was regarded as the end-date of a 5,126-year-long cycle in the [Mesoamerican Long Count calendar](/wiki/Mesoamerican_Long_Count_calendar)and as such, festivities to commemorate the date took place on 21 December 2012 in the countries that were part of the [Maya civilization](/wiki/Maya_civilization)(Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador), with main events at [Chichén Itzá](/wiki/Chich%C3%A9n_Itz%C3%A1)in Mexico and [Tikal](/wiki/Tikal)in Guatemala. Professional [Mayanist](/wiki/Mayanist)scholars stated that no extant [classic Maya accounts](/wiki/Maya_codices)forecast impending doom and that the idea that the Long Count calendar ends in 2012 misrepresented [Maya history](/wiki/Maya_civilization#History)and culture, [[2]](#cite_note-2)while astronomers rejected the various proposed doomsday scenarios easily refuted by elementary astronomical observations. [[3]](#cite_note-3) [Ancient astronauts](/wiki/Ancient_astronauts)- a concept based on the belief that intelligent [extraterrestrial beings](/wiki/Extraterrestrial_life)visited Earth and made contact with humans in [antiquity](/wiki/Ancient_history)and [prehistoric](/wiki/Prehistoric)times. Proponents suggest that this contact influenced the development of modern cultures, technologies and religions. A common claim is that [deities](/wiki/Deity)from most, if not all, religions are actually extraterrestrial in origin and that advanced technologies brought to Earth by ancient astronauts were interpreted as evidence of divine status by early humans. The idea that ancient astronauts existed is not taken seriously by academics and has received no credible attention in [peer-reviewed](/wiki/Peer-review)studies. [[4]](#cite_note-4) [Anunnaki from Nibiru (Sitchin)](/wiki/Ancient_astronauts#Zecharia_Sitchin)(variant) - proposed by [Zecharia Sitchin](/wiki/Zecharia_Sitchin)in his series The Earth Chronicles, beginning with The 12th Planet (1976), it revolves around Sitchin's unique interpretation of ancient [Sumerian](/wiki/Sumerian_language)and [Middle Eastern](/wiki/Middle_East)texts, megalithic sites, and artifacts from around the world. He hypothesizes that the gods of old [Mesopotamia](/wiki/Mesopotamia)were actually astronauts from the planet " [Nibiru](/wiki/Nibiru_(Sitchin))", which Sitchin claims the Sumerians believed was a remote "12th planet" (counting the Sun, Moon and Pluto as planets) associated with the god [Marduk](/wiki/Marduk). According to Sitchin, Nibiru continues to orbit the Sun on a 3,600-year orbit. [[5]](#cite_note-Skepdic-5) [Ancient astronauts Temple](/wiki/Robert_K._G._Temple)'s proposal Sirius Mystery](/wiki/The_Sirius_Mystery)(1976) argues that the [Dogon people](/wiki/Dogon_people)of northwestern [Mali](/wiki/Mali)preserved an account of extraterrestrial visitation from around 5,000 years ago. He quotes various lines of evidence, including supposed advanced astronomical knowledge inherited by the tribe, descriptions, and comparative belief systems with ancient civilizations such as [ancient Egypt](/wiki/Ancient_Egypt)and [Sumer](/wiki/Sumer). [[6]](#cite_note-Temple_1999_p.-6) - [Astrology](/wiki/Astrology)(see also [Astrology and science](/wiki/Astrology_and_science)) - consists of a number of belief systems that hold that there is a relationship between astronomical phenomena and events or descriptions of personality in the human world. Several systems of divination are based on the [relative positions and movement](/wiki/Apparent_retrograde_motion#Apparent_motion)of various real and construed celestial bodies. [Scientific testing](/wiki/Astrology#Scientific_analysis_and_criticism)of astrology has been conducted and no evidence has been found to support the premises or purported effects outlined in astrological traditions. [[7]](#cite_note-Zarka-7)Where astrology has made [falsifiable](/wiki/Falsifiable)predictions, it has been falsified. [[7]](#cite_note-Zarka-7): 424 [Creationist cosmologies](/wiki/Creationist_cosmologies)are explanations of the origins and form of the [universe](/wiki/Universe)in terms of the [Genesis creation narrative](/wiki/Genesis_creation_narrative)(Genesis 1), according to which the [God](/wiki/God)of the Bible created the cosmos in eight creative acts over the six days of the "creation week". [[8]](#cite_note-Hendel_2013_p.-8) - Evidence for [life on Mars](/wiki/Life_on_Mars) on Mars](/wiki/Cydonia_(region_of_Mars)#"Face_on_Mars")is a rock formation in [Cydonia Mensae](/wiki/Cydonia_(region_of_Mars))on Mars asserted to be evidence of intelligent, native life on the planet. High-resolution images taken recently show it to appear less face-like. [[9]](#cite_note-NASA_face-9)It features prominently in the works of [Richard C. Hoagland](/wiki/Richard_C._Hoagland)and [Tom Van Flandern](/wiki/Tom_Van_Flandern). [[10]](#cite_note-Hoagland_2001_p.-10) [[11]](#cite_note-Flandern_1998_p.-11)This effect can also be explained by the psychological phenomenon [pareidolia](/wiki/Pareidolia), whereby one assigns meaning (such as facial perception) to an otherwise ambiguous or meaningless stimulus. [Lunar effect](/wiki/Lunar_effect)- the belief that the full Moon influences human behavior. [[12]](#cite_note-skepdic_lunar-12) [Modern flat Earth beliefs](/wiki/Modern_flat_Earth_beliefs)propose that Earth is a flat, disc-shaped planet that accelerates upward, producing the illusion of [gravity](/wiki/Gravity). Proposers of a flat Earth, such as the [Flat Earth Research Society](/wiki/International_Flat_Earth_Research_Society), do not accept compelling evidence, such as photos of Earth from space. [[13]](#cite_note-Dure_2016-13) [Modern geocentrism](/wiki/Modern_geocentrism)- In astronomy, the geocentric model (also known as geocentrism or the Ptolemaic system) is a [superseded](/wiki/Superseded_scientific_theories)description of the universe with Earth at the center. Under the geocentric model, the Sun, Moon, stars and planets all circled Earth. The geocentric model served as the predominant description of the cosmos in many ancient civilizations, such as those of Aristotle and Ptolemy. [[14]](#cite_note-Numbers_1993_p.-14) [Moon landing conspiracy theories](/wiki/Moon_landing_conspiracy_theories)- claim that some or all elements of the [Apollo program](/wiki/Apollo_program)and the associated Moon landings were hoaxes staged by NASA with the aid of other organizations. The most notable claim is that the six crewed landings (1969-72) were faked and that 12 Apollo astronauts did not actually walk on the Moon. Various groups and individuals have made claims since the mid-1970s that NASA and others knowingly misled the public into believing the landings happened by manufacturing, tampering with or destroying evidence, including photos, telemetry tapes, radio and TV transmissions and Moon rock samples, and even killing some key witnesses. [[15]](#cite_note-Plait_2002_p.-15) [Nibiru cataclysm](/wiki/Nibiru_cataclysm)- a prediction first made by [contactee](/wiki/Contactee)Nancy Lieder that a mythological planet [Nibiru](/wiki/Nibiru_(Sitchin))would collide with Earth. After having adjusted her prediction many times, she later claimed the year of the occurrence to be 2012. [[16]](#cite_note-16)In 2017, a [conspiracy theorist](/wiki/Conspiracy_theory)known as Nibiru would hit. [Vaimnika Shstra](/wiki/Vaim%C4%81nika_Sh%C4%81stra)- claim that airplanes were invented in [ancient India](/wiki/Ancient_India)during the [Vedic period](/wiki/Vedic_period). A 1974 study by researchers at the [Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore](/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Science,_Bangalore)found that the heavier-than-air aircraft that the Vaimnika Shstra described were aerodynamically unfeasible. The authors remarked that the discussion of the principles of flight in the text were largely perfunctory and incorrect, in some cases violating [Newton's laws of motion](/wiki/Newton%27s_laws_of_motion). [[17]](#cite_note-17) [Worlds in Collision](/wiki/Worlds_in_Collision)- writer [Immanuel Velikovsky](/wiki/Immanuel_Velikovsky)proposed in his book Worlds in Collision that ancient texts and geographic evidence show mankind was witness to catastrophic interactions of other planets in our Solar System. [[18]](#cite_note-18) Earth sciences [Megalithic geometry](/wiki/Pseudoscientific_metrology#"Megalithic_geometry")or 366 geometry - posits the existence of an [Earth](/wiki/Earth)-based [geometry](/wiki/Geometry)dating back to at least 3500 BCE and the possibility that such a system is still in use in modern [Freemasonry](/wiki/Freemasonry). According to proponents, [megalithic](/wiki/Megalithic)civilizations in Britain and Brittany had advanced knowledge of geometry and the size of Earth. The [megalithic yard](/wiki/Megalithic_yard)is correlated to the polar circumference of Earth using a circle divided into 366 degrees. [[19]](#cite_note-HistoryOfComputers-19) [[20]](#cite_note-NISTReport-20) - The [Bermuda Triangle](/wiki/Bermuda_Triangle)- a region of the Atlantic Ocean that lies between Bermuda, Puerto Rico and (in its most popular version) Florida. Ship and aircraft disasters and disappearances perceived as frequent in this area have led to the circulation of stories of unusual natural phenomena, paranormal encounters and interactions with [extraterrestrials](/wiki/Extraterrestrial_life). [[21]](#cite_note-NOVA,1976-21) [Climate change denial](/wiki/Climate_change_denial)- involves denial, dismissal, unwarranted doubt or contrarian views which depart from the scientific consensus on [climate change](/wiki/Climate_change), including the extent to which it is caused by humans, its impacts on nature and human society, or the potential of adaptation to global warming by human actions. [[22]](#cite_note-22) [[23]](#cite_note-NCSE-why-denial-23) [[24]](#cite_note-24) [Flood geology](/wiki/Flood_geology)- creationist form of geology that advocates most of the geologic features on Earth are explainable by a [global flood](/wiki/Deluge_(mythology)). [[25]](#cite_note-NCSE_2016-25) - The [Hollow Earth](/wiki/Hollow_Earth)- a proposal that Earth is either entirely hollow or consists of hollow sections beneath the crust. Certain folklore and conspiracy theories hold this idea and suggest the existence of subterranean life. [[26]](#cite_note-Storr_2014-26) [Welteislehre](/wiki/Welteislehre), a.k.a. the World Ice Theory or Glacial Cosmogony - ice is proposed to be the basic substance of all cosmic processes and ice moons, ice planets and the "global ether" (also made of ice) had determined the entire development of the universe. Physics [Autodynamics](/wiki/Autodynamics)- a physics theory proposed in the 1940s that claims the equations of the Lorentz transformation are incorrectly formulated to describe relativistic effects, which would invalidate Einstein's theories of special relativity and general relativity, and Maxwell's equations. The theory is discounted by the mainstream physics community. [[27]](#cite_note-Wired-27) [E-Cat](/wiki/E-Cat)- a claimed cold fusion reactor. [[28]](#cite_note-patent_app-28) [[29]](#cite_note-zyga-29) [Einstein-Cartan-Evans theory](/wiki/Einstein%E2%80%93Cartan%E2%80%93Evans_theory)- a unified theory of physics proposed by Myron Wyn Evans which claims to unify general relativity, quantum mechanics and electromagnetism. [[30]](#cite_note-AIAS-30)The hypothesis was largely published in the journal Foundations of Physics Letters between 2003 and 2005; in 2008, the editor published an editorial note effectively retracting the journal's support for the hypothesis due to incorrect mathematical claims. [[31]](#cite_note-31) [Electrogravitics](/wiki/Electrogravitics)- claimed to be an unconventional type of effect or anti-gravity propulsion created by an electric field's effect on a mass. The name was coined in the 1920s by Thomas Townsend Brown, who first described the effect and spent most of his life trying to develop it and sell it as a propulsion system. Follow-ups on the claims (R. L. Talley in a 1990 U.S. Air Force study, NASA scientist Jonathan Campbell in a 2003 experiment [[32]](#cite_note-32)and [Martin Tajmar](/wiki/Martin_Tajmar)in a 2004 paper [[33]](#cite_note-33)) have found that no thrust could be observed in a vacuum, consistent with the phenomenon of ion wind. [Free energy](/wiki/Free_energy_suppression)- a class of [perpetual motion](/wiki/Perpetual_motion)that purports to create energy (violating the [first law of thermodynamics](/wiki/First_law_of_thermodynamics)) or extract useful work from equilibrium systems (violating the [second law of thermodynamics](/wiki/Second_law_of_thermodynamics)). [[34]](#cite_note-34) [[35]](#cite_note-Milbank-35) [Water-fueled cars](/wiki/Water-fueled_car)- an instance of perpetual motion machines. Such devices are claimed to use water as fuel or produce fuel from water on board with no other energy input. Many such claims are part of [investment frauds](/wiki/Investment_fraud). [[36]](#cite_note-Times-36) [[37]](#cite_note-37) [[38]](#cite_note-Dingel-38) [Gasoline pill](/wiki/Gasoline_pill)or gasoline powder, to turn water into gasoline. [[39]](#cite_note-nydailynews.com_2008-39) [Hongcheng Magic Liquid](/wiki/Hongcheng_Magic_Liquid)- a scam in China in which Wang Hongcheng (Chinese: ; pinyin: Wáng Hóngchéng), a bus driver from Harbin with no scientific education, claimed in 1983 that he could turn regular water into a fuel as flammable as petrol by simply dissolving a few drops of his liquid in it. [[40]](#cite_note-csicop_hongcheng-40) - - Hydrinos (Randell L. Mills/ [Brilliant Light Power Inc.](/wiki/Brilliant_Light_Power)) - a supposed state of the [hydrogen atom](/wiki/Hydrogen_atom)that, according to Mills, is of lower energy than [ground state](/wiki/Ground_state)and has extremely high efficiency as a fuel. [[41]](#cite_note-parkorigin-41)Critics say it lacks corroborating scientific evidence and is a relic of [cold fusion](/wiki/Cold_fusion). Critical analysis of the claims have been published in the peer reviewed journals [Physics Letters A](/wiki/Physics_Letters_A), [New Journal of Physics](/wiki/New_Journal_of_Physics), [Journal of Applied Physics](/wiki/Journal_of_Applied_Physics), and [Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics](/wiki/Journal_of_Physics_D:_Applied_Physics)stating that the proposed hydrino states are unphysical and incompatible with key equations of quantum mechanics. [[42]](#cite_note-dombey-42) [Orgone](/wiki/Orgone)- a pseudoscientific concept described as an [esoteric energy](/wiki/Energy_(esotericism))or hypothetical universal [life force](/wiki/Energy_(esotericism)), originally proposed in the 1930s. [[43]](#cite_note-43) [[44]](#cite_note-blumenfeld-44) Applied sciences Agriculture [Lysenkoism](/wiki/Lysenkoism), or Lysenko-Michurinism - was a political campaign against genetics and science-based agriculture conducted by [Trofim Lysenko](/wiki/Trofim_Lysenko), his followers and Soviet authorities. Lysenko served as the director of the Soviet Union's Lenin All-Union Academy of Agricultural Sciences. Lysenkoism began in the late 1920s and formally ended in 1964. The pseudoscientific ideas of Lysenkoism built on Lamarckian concepts of the heritability of acquired characteristics. [[45]](#cite_note-45)Lysenko's theory rejected Mendelian inheritance and the concept of the "gene"; it departed from Darwinian evolutionary theory by rejecting natural selection, viewing that concept as being incompatible with Marxist ideology. [[46]](#cite_note-Perversion_of_Knowledge-46) [Biodynamic agriculture](/wiki/Biodynamic_agriculture)- method of [organic farming](/wiki/Organic_farming)that treats farms as unified and individual organisms. Biodynamics uses a calendar which has been characterized as [astrological](/wiki/Astrological). The substances and composts used by biodynamicists have been described as unconventional and [homeopathic](/wiki/Homeopathy). For example, field mice are countered by deploying ashes prepared from field mice skin when Venus is in the Scorpius constellation. No difference in beneficial outcomes has been scientifically established between certified biodynamic agricultural techniques and similar organic and [integrated farming](/wiki/Integrated_farming)practices. Biodynamic agriculture lacks strong scientific evidence for its efficacy and has been labeled a [pseudoscience](/wiki/Pseudoscience)because of its overreliance upon esoteric knowledge and mystical beliefs. [[47]](#cite_note-demarc-47) [GMO skepticism](/wiki/Genetically_modified_food_controversies#Health)- The belief that genetically modified foods are inherently unsafe. This contradicts the [scientific consensus](/wiki/Scientific_consensus). [[48]](#cite_note-Nicolia2013-48) [[49]](#cite_note-FAO-49) [[50]](#cite_note-Ronald2011-50) [[51]](#cite_note-Also-51) [aesthetics](/wiki/Aesthetics)based on [astronomy](/wiki/Chinese_astronomy), [geography](/wiki/Geography)and the putative flow of [qi](/wiki/Qi). Evidence for its effectiveness is based on anecdote and there is a lack of a plausible method of action; this leads to conflicting advice from different practitioners of feng shui. Feng shui practitioners use this as evidence of variations or different schools; critical analysts have described it thus: "Feng shui has always been based upon mere guesswork." [[52]](#cite_note-duke-52) [[53]](#cite_note-53)Modern criticism differentiates between feng shui as a traditional proto-religion and the modern practice: "A naturalistic belief, it was originally used to find an auspicious dwelling place for a shrine or a tomb. However, over the centuries it...has become distorted and degraded into a gross superstition." [[52]](#cite_note-duke-52) [Ley lines](/wiki/Ley_line)- proposed intentional alignment of ancient monuments and landscape features was later explained by a statistical analysis of lines that concluded: "the density of archaeological sites in the British landscape is so great that a line drawn through virtually anywhere will 'clip' a number of sites." [[54]](#cite_note-54)Additional [New Age](/wiki/New_Age)and feng shui concepts have been proposed building on the original concept and pseudoscientific claims about energy flowing through the lines have been made. [Minimum parking requirements](/wiki/Parking_minimums_and_maximums)- system for assigning an optimal number of parking spaces to a given land use. It is characterized as a pseudoscience by UCLA planning professor [Donald Shoup](/wiki/Donald_Shoup), especially as practiced by the [Institute of Transportation Engineers](/wiki/Institute_of_Transportation_Engineers). He argues that the ITE's calculations are arcane, overly specific, and typically based on minimal data and approximations that cannot be widely applied to other businesses, even of the same type, and yet are presented as science-backed. [[55]](#cite_note-55) [[56]](#cite_note-56) [Vastu shastra](/wiki/Vastu_shastra)is the ancient Hindu system of architecture, which lays down a series of rules for building houses in relation to ambiance. [[57]](#cite_note-57)Vastu Shastra is considered pseudoscience by astronomer [Jayant Narlikar](/wiki/Jayant_Narlikar), who writes that Vastu does not have any "logical connection" to the environment. [[59]](#cite_note-narlikar_CUP-59) Finance [Technical analysis](/wiki/Technical_analysis)is a [security analysis](/wiki/Security_analysis)methodology for forecasting the direction of [prices](/wiki/Prices)through the study of past market data, primarily price and volume. [[60]](#cite_note-Kirk-60) [Behavioral economics](/wiki/Behavioral_economics)and [quantitative analysis](/wiki/Quantitative_analysis_(finance))use many of technical analysis, [[61]](#cite_note-61) [[62]](#cite_note-62) [[63]](#cite_note-MizrachWeerts2007-63) [[64]](#cite_note-64)which, being an aspect of [active management](/wiki/Active_management), stands in contradiction to much of [modern portfolio theory](/wiki/Modern_portfolio_theory). The efficacy of both technical and [fundamental analysis](/wiki/Fundamental_analysis)is disputed by the [efficient-market hypothesis](/wiki/Efficient-market_hypothesis), which states that stock market prices are essentially unpredictable. [[65]](#cite_note-65)It is still considered by many academics to be [pseudoscience](/wiki/Pseudoscience). [[66]](#cite_note-Paulos2003-66)Academics such as [Eugene Fama](/wiki/Eugene_Fama)say the evidence for technical analysis is sparse and is inconsistent with the [weak form](/wiki/Efficient-market_hypothesis#Weak-form_efficiency)of the efficient-market hypothesis. [[67]](#cite_note-autogenerated1-67) [[68]](#cite_note-68) Health and medicine Pseudoscientific medical practices are often known as [quackery](/wiki/Quackery). In contrast, modern medicine is (or seeks to be) [evidence-based](/wiki/Evidence-based_medicine). [Acupuncture](/wiki/Acupuncture)- use of fine needles to stimulate acupuncture points and balance the flow of qi. There is no known [anatomical](/wiki/Anatomical)or [histological](/wiki/Histological)basis for the existence of acupuncture points or meridians and acupuncture is regarded as an alternative medical procedure. [[69]](#cite_note-Barrett2007-69)Some acupuncturists regard them as functional rather than structural entities, useful in guiding evaluation and care of patients. Acupuncture has been the subject of active [scientific](/wiki/Scientific_method)research since the late 20th century and its effects and application remain controversial among medical researchers and clinicians. Some scholarly reviews conclude that acupuncture's effects are mainly attributable to the [placebo effect](/wiki/Placebo_effect)and others find likelihood of efficacy for particular conditions. [Dry needling](/wiki/Dry_needling)is the therapeutic insertion of fine needles without regard to [traditional Chinese medicine](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine)(TCM) and is similarly controversial. [[70]](#cite_note-ncbi.nlm.nih.gov-70) [[71]](#cite_note-71) [Acupressure](/wiki/Acupressure)is an alternative medicine technique similar in principle to [acupuncture](/wiki/Acupuncture). It is based on the concept of life energy, which flows through "meridians" in the body. In treatment, physical pressure is applied to [acupuncture points](/wiki/Acupuncture_point)with the aim of clearing blockages in these meridians. Pressure may be applied by hand, by elbow, or with various devices. Some studies have suggested it may be effective at helping manage nausea and vomiting, lower back pain, tension headaches and stomach ache, although such studies have been found to have a high likelihood of bias. [[72]](#cite_note-Lee-72)Like many alternative medicines, it may benefit from a [placebo effect](/wiki/Placebo_effect). [Quackwatch](/wiki/Quackwatch)says acupressure is a dubious practice and its practitioners use irrational methods. [[73]](#cite_note-Quackwatch-73) - [Addiction recovery 12-step models](/wiki/12_step_program), which rely on a view of addiction and alcoholism as "spiritual diseases" for which the only remedy (although not a cure, as this view defines addiction as chronic and incurable) is a "spiritual conversion" in which a person must surrender their will to a deity. [[74]](#cite_note-74) [[75]](#cite_note-75) [Adrenal fatigue](/wiki/Adrenal_fatigue)or hypoadrenia is a pseudoscientific diagnosis described as a state in which the [adrenal glands](/wiki/Adrenal_gland)are exhausted and unable to produce adequate quantities of [hormones](/wiki/Hormone), primarily the [glucocorticoid](/wiki/Glucocorticoid) [cortisol](/wiki/Cortisol), due to chronic stress or infections. [[76]](#cite_note-2012Rev-76)Adrenal fatigue should not be confused with a number of actual forms of adrenal dysfunction [Addison's disease](/wiki/Addison%27s_disease). [[77]](#cite_note-webmd-77)The term "adrenal fatigue", which in 1998 by James Wilson, a [chiropractor](/wiki/Chiropractic), [[78]](#cite_note-sbm-78)may be applied to a collection of mostly [nonspecific symptoms](/wiki/Nonspecific_symptoms). [[76]](#cite_note-2012Rev-76)There is no [scientific evidence](/wiki/Scientific_evidence)supporting the concept of adrenal fatigue and it is not recognized as a diagnosis by any scientific or medical community. [[76]](#cite_note-2012Rev-76) [[77]](#cite_note-webmd-77)A systematic review found no evidence for the term adrenal fatigue, confirming the consensus among endocrinological societies that it is a myth. [[79]](#cite_note-79) - The [Alexander Technique](/wiki/Alexander_Technique), named after its creator [Frederick Matthias Alexander](/wiki/Frederick_Matthias_Alexander), is an educational process that was created to retrain habitual patterns of movement and posture. Alexander believed that [poor habits in posture](/wiki/Poor_posture)and movement damaged spatial [self-awareness](/wiki/Self-awareness)as well as health and that movement efficiency could support overall physical well-being. He saw the technique as a mental training technique as well. [[80]](#cite_note-blochLP-80): 221 Alexander began developing his technique's principles in the 1890s [[81]](#cite_note-81)in an attempt to address [voice loss](/wiki/Voice_loss)during public speaking. [[80]](#cite_note-blochLP-80): 34-35 He credited his method with allowing him to pursue his passion for reciting in [Shakespearean](/wiki/Shakespearean)theater. [[82]](#cite_note-82)Some proponents of the Alexander Technique say that it addresses a variety of health conditions related to cumulative physical behaviors, but there is little evidence to support many of the claims made about the technique. [[83]](#cite_note-aus17LP-83) [[84]](#cite_note-NHSLP-84)As of 2015, there was evidence suggesting the Alexander Technique may be helpful for both long-term [back pain](/wiki/Back_pain)and long-term [neck pain](/wiki/Neck_pain)and may help people cope with [Parkinson's disease](/wiki/Parkinson%27s_disease). [[84]](#cite_note-NHSLP-84)However, both [Aetna](/wiki/Aetna)and the Australian Department of Health have conducted reviews and concluded that the technique has insufficient evidence to warrant insurance coverage. [[83]](#cite_note-aus17LP-83) [Alternative cancer treatments](/wiki/Alternative_cancer_treatments)are [alternative or complementary treatments](/wiki/Alternative_medicine)for [cancer](/wiki/Cancer)that have not been approved by the government agencies responsible for the [regulation of therapeutic goods](/wiki/Regulation_of_therapeutic_goods)and have not undergone properly conducted, well-designed clinical trials. Among those that have been published, the methodology is often poor. A 2006 systematic review of 214 articles covering 198 clinical trials of alternative cancer treatments concluded that almost none conducted [dose-ranging](/wiki/Dose-ranging)studies, which are necessary to ensure that the patients are being given a useful amount of the treatment. [[85]](#cite_note-Vickers2006-85)These kinds of treatments appear and vanish frequently and have done so throughout history. [[86]](#cite_note-Cassileth1996-86) [Alternative or fringe medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine)- The terms alternative medicine, complementary medicine, integrative medicine, holistic medicine, natural medicine, unorthodox medicine, fringe medicine, unconventional medicine and [New Age](/wiki/New_Age)medicine are used interchangeably and are almost synonymous. [[87]](#cite_note-Shapiro_08-87)Terminology shifts over time to reflect the branding of practitioners. [[88]](#cite_note-SBM-brand-88)Therapies are often [framed](/wiki/Framing_(psychology))as "natural" or "holistic", implicitly and intentionally suggesting that conventional "artificial" and "narrow in scope". [[89]](#cite_note-ConsumerHealth9th-89) [[90]](#cite_note-90) [Animal magnetism](/wiki/Animal_magnetism)- also known as was the name given by German doctor [Franz Mesmer](/wiki/Franz_Mesmer)in the 18th century to what he believed to be an invisible natural force (Lebensmagnetismus) possessed by all living things, including humans, animals and vegetables. He believed that the force could have physical effects, including healing, and he tried persistently but without success to achieve scientific recognition of his ideas. [[173]](#cite_note-osterholm-173) - The [Craniosacral therapy](/wiki/Craniosacral_therapy)- is a form of bodywork or alternative therapy using gentle touch to manipulate the synarthrodial joints of the cranium. Practitioners believe that this manipulation regulates the flow of cerebrospinal fluid and aids in "primary respiration." Craniosacral therapy was developed by John Upledger, D.O. in the 1970s as an offshoot of osteopathy in the cranial field, or cranial osteopathy, which was developed in the 1930s by William Garner Sutherland. According to the American Cancer Society, although CST may relieve the symptoms of stress or tension, "available scientific evidence does not support claims that craniosacral therapy helps in treating cancer or any other disease." [[534]](#cite_note-536)Well-known examples of creatures of interest to cryptozoologists include [Bigfoot](/wiki/Bigfoot), the [Yeren](/wiki/Yeren), the [Yeti](/wiki/Yeti), and "Cryptozoology ranges from pseudoscientific to interesting, depending on how it is practiced." [[271]](#cite_note-Shermer2002-271) [Dowsing](/wiki/Dowsing)refers to practices said to enable one to detect hidden water, metals, gemstones or other objects. [[342]](#cite_note-saf-342) [[344]](#cite_note-scientificamerican-344) [Electronic voice phenomenon](/wiki/Electronic_voice_phenomenon)- purported communication by spirits through devices. [[535]](#cite_note-537) [[536]](#cite_note-alcock1-538) [[537]](#cite_note-Carroll_2003-539) [[538]](#cite_note-540) [[539]](#cite_note-541) [Extra-sensory perception](/wiki/Extra-sensory_perception)- paranormal ability (independent of the five main [senses](/wiki/Sense)or deduction from previous experience) to acquire information by means such as [locations](/wiki/List_of_reportedly_haunted_locations)that are reported to be haunted by [ghosts](/wiki/Ghost). Typically, a ghost-hunting team will attempt to collect evidence supporting the existence of [paranormal](/wiki/Paranormal)activity. Ghost hunters use a variety of electronic devices, including [EMF meters](/wiki/EMF_meter), digital [thermometers](/wiki/Thermometer), both handheld vision cameras](/wiki/Night_vision), as well as digital [audio recorders](/wiki/Dictation_machine). Other more traditional techniques are also used, such as conducting [interviews](/wiki/Interview)and [researching](/wiki/Research)the [history](/wiki/History)of allegedly haunted sites. Ghost hunters may also refer to themselves as "paranormal investigators." [[543]](#cite_note-MiamiHeraldghost-545)Ghost hunting has been heavily criticized for its dismissal of the [scientific method](/wiki/Scientific_method). No scientific study has ever been able to confirm the existence of ghosts. [[544]](#cite_note-ShadyScienceghost-546) [[545]](#cite_note-547)The practice is considered a [pseudoscience](/wiki/Pseudoscience)by the vast majority of educators, academics, science writers, [Lizard people](/wiki/Reptilian_conspiracy_theory)- The idea of a reptilian reconquest was popularized by David Icke, a conspiracy theorist who claims shape-shifting reptilian aliens control Earth by taking on human form and gaining political power to manipulate human societies. Icke has stated on multiple occasions that many world leaders are, or are possessed by, so-called reptilians. [Levitation](/wiki/Metaphysical_levitation)- act of rising up from the ground without any physical aids, usually by the power of thought. [[554]](#cite_note-556) [Palmistry](/wiki/Palmistry)- the belief that the future can be foretold through palm reading. Predictions are based on the shape, line, and mounts of the hands. Palmists use [cold reading](/wiki/Cold_reading)in order to appear psychic. [[555]](#cite_note-557) [Parapsychology](/wiki/Parapsychology)- (see [Psychology](#Psychology)section above) [Pseudoarchaeology](/wiki/Pseudoarchaeology)- investigation of the ancient past using alleged paranormal or other means which have not been validated by mainstream science. [[271]](#cite_note-Shermer2002-271) [Psychic surgery](/wiki/Psychic_surgery)- a type of medical fraud, popular in [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil)and the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines). Practitioners use sleight of hand to make it appear as though they are reaching into a patient's body and extracting "tumors". Psychic surgery is usually explicit deception; i.e., the "practitioners" are aware that they are or "quackery". [[271]](#cite_note-Shermer2002-271) - The [Tunguska event](/wiki/Tunguska_event)was an actual large explosion, possibly caused by a [meteoroid](/wiki/Meteoroid)or [comet](/wiki/Comet), in what is now [Krasnoyarsk Krai](/wiki/Krasnoyarsk_Krai), Russia in June 1908. Night skies as far away as London were markedly brighter for several evenings. Unsupported theories regarding the event include the impact of a miniature black hole or large body of [antimatter](/wiki/Antimatter), [ball lightning](/wiki/Ball_lightning), a test by [Nikola and a [UFO](/wiki/Unidentified_flying_object)crash. [[271]](#cite_note-Shermer2002-271) [[563]](#cite_note-Stableford2006-565) [[564]](#cite_note-566)Another theory is that the explosion was caused by a piece of [Biela's Comet](/wiki/Biela%27s_Comet)from 1883. [[565]](#cite_note-567) [Ufology](/wiki/Ufology)- the study of [unidentified flying objects](/wiki/Unidentified_flying_object)(UFOs) that sometimes includes the belief that UFOs - a set of beliefs in a divine, [mystical](/wiki/Mysticism), or other special relationship between a [number](/wiki/Number)and [coinciding](/wiki/Coincidence#Interpretation)events. similar [divinatory](/wiki/Divination)arts. [[571]](#cite_note-573) [Scriptural codes](/wiki/Bible_code)- the belief that a book or fragment of [holy scripture](/wiki/Holy_scripture)contains encoded messages that impart esoteric knowledge. One such decoding method involves identifying "equidistant letter sequences" that spell out such messages. [[572]](#cite_note-574) Religious and spiritual beliefs Spiritual and religious practices and beliefs, according to astronomer [Carl Sagan](/wiki/Carl_Sagan), are normally not classified as pseudoscience. [[573]](#cite_note-sagan1996-575) However, religion can sometimes nurture pseudoscience, and "at the extremes it is difficult to distinguish pseudoscience from rigid, doctrinaire religion", and some religions might be confused with pseudoscience, such as traditional meditation. [[573]](#cite_note-sagan1996-575) The following religious/spiritual items have been related to or classified as pseudoscience in some way: [Affirmative prayer](/wiki/Affirmative_prayer)is a form of [prayer](/wiki/Prayer)or a [metaphysical](/wiki/Metaphysics)technique that is focused on a positive outcome, rather than a negative situation. For instance, a person who is experiencing some form of illness would focus the prayer on the desired state of perfect health and affirm this desired intention "as if already happened" rather than identifying the illness and then asking God for help to eliminate it. [William James](/wiki/William_James)described affirmative prayer as an element of the American metaphysical healing movement that he called the "mind-cure"; he described it as America's "only decidedly original contribution to the systemic philosophy of life." [[574]](#cite_note-Zaleski-576)What sets affirmative prayer apart from secular [affirmations](/wiki/Affirmations_(New_Age))of the [autosuggestion](/wiki/Autosuggestion)type taught by the 19th century [self-help](/wiki/Self-help)author [Émile Coué](/wiki/%C3%89mile_Cou%C3%A9)(whose most famous affirmation was "Every day in every way, I am getting better and better") is that affirmative prayer addresses the practitioner to God, the Divine, the Creative Mind, emphasizing the seemingly practical aspects of religious belief. [[575]](#cite_note-Inge-577) [Christian Science](/wiki/Christian_Science)is generally considered a [Christian](/wiki/Christianity) [new religious movement](/wiki/New_religious_movement); however, some have called it "pseudoscience" because its founder, [Mary Baker Eddy](/wiki/Mary_Baker_Eddy), used "science" in its name, and because of its former stance against medical science. Also, "Eddy used the term Metaphysical science to distinguish her system both from materialistic science and from occult science." [[576]](#cite_note-578)The church now accepts the use of medical science. Vaccinations were banned, but in 1901, Eddy, at the age of 80, advised her followers to submit to them. [[577]](#cite_note-579) [Energy](/wiki/Energy_(esotericism))is used by writers and practitioners of various [esoteric](/wiki/Esoteric)forms of [spirituality](/wiki/Spirituality)and [alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine)to refer to a variety of claimed experiences and phenomena that defy measurement and thus can be distinguished from the [scientific form of energy](/wiki/Energy). [[578]](#cite_note-Stengerenergy-580) [[579]](#cite_note-Smithenergy-581)There is no existence of such energy. [[578]](#cite_note-Stengerenergy-580) [[579]](#cite_note-Smithenergy-581) [[580]](#cite_note-energyenergy-582)Therapies that purport to use, modify, or manipulate unknown energies are thus among the most contentious of all complementary and [alternative medicines](/wiki/Alternative_medicine). Claims related to energy therapies are most often [anecdotal](/wiki/Anecdotal_evidence)(from single stories), rather than being based or spiritual practice of evicting [demons](/wiki/Demon)or other spiritual entities from a person, or an area, that is believed to be [possessed](/wiki/Demonic_possession). Depending on the spiritual beliefs of the [exorcist](/wiki/Exorcist), this may be done by causing the entity to swear an oath, performing an elaborate [ritual](/wiki/Ritual), or simply by commanding it to depart in the name of a higher power. The practice is ancient and part of the belief system of many cultures and religions. Requested and performed exorcism began to decline in the United States by the 18th century and occurred rarely until the latter half of the 20th century, when the public saw a sharp rise due to the media attention exorcisms were getting. There was "a 50% increase in the number of exorcisms performed between the early 1960s and the mid-1970s". [Koranic scientific foreknowledge](/wiki/Islamic_attitudes_towards_science)(or Qur'anic science or Hadeeth science) asserts that foundational Islamic religious texts made accurate statements about the world that science verified hundreds of years later. [[583]](#cite_note-LewisHammer2011-585)This belief is a common theme in [Bucailleism](/wiki/Maurice_Bucaille#Bucailleism). [[584]](#cite_note-Kuiper_2021-586) [[585]](#cite_note-Hameed2019-587)According to Turkish American physicist [Taner Edis](/wiki/Taner_Edis), many Muslims appreciate technology and respect the role that science plays in its creation. As a result, he says there is a great deal of Islamic [pseudoscience](/wiki/Pseudoscience)attempting to reconcile science with their religious beliefs. [[586]](#cite_note-Edis2009ScienceEducation-588) [[587]](#cite_note-EdisFreeInquiry-589)Edis maintains that the motivation to read modern scientific truths into holy books is also stronger for Muslims than Christians. [[588]](#cite_note-TanerEdis-590)This is because, according to Edis, true criticism of the Quran is almost non-existent in the Muslim world, causing Muslims to believe that scientific truths simply must appear in the Quran. [[588]](#cite_note-TanerEdis-590) Creation science [Creation science](/wiki/Creation_science) or scientific creationism is a branch of creationism that claims to provide scientific support for the Genesis creation narrative in the Book of Genesis and disprove or reexplain the scientific facts, theories and scientific paradigms about geology, cosmology, biological evolution, archaeology, history and linguistics. [[589]](#cite_note-591)[ [failed verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability)] called "created kinds" or "baramins" according to the account of creation in the book of Genesis and other parts of the Bible. [Flood geology](/wiki/Flood_geology)- creationist form of geology that advocates most of the geologic features on Earth are burial site of [Noah's Ark](/wiki/Noah%27s_Ark)that, according to the [Genesis flood narrative](/wiki/Genesis_flood_narrative), is located somewhere in the alleged " [Mountains of Ararat](/wiki/Mountains_of_Ararat)". There have been numerous expeditions with several false claims of success; the practice is widely regarded as that "certain features of the universe and of living things are best explained by an intelligent cause, not an undirected process such as natural selection." It is used by proponents of intelligent design to argue that evolution by [natural selection](/wiki/Natural_selection)alone is incomplete or flawed, and that some additional mechanism (an "Intelligent Designer") is required to explain the [[602]](#cite_note-604) [[603]](#cite_note-605) [[604]](#cite_note-606) [[605]](#cite_note-Decker-607) [Specified complexity](/wiki/Specified_complexity)- claim that when something is simultaneously complex and specified, one can infer that it was produced by an intelligent cause (i.e., that it was designed) rather than being the result of natural processes. [[486]](#cite_note-council-486) [[600]](#cite_note-ReferenceA-602) - Scientology [Dianetics](/wiki/Dianetics), a therapeutic technique promoted by [Scientology](/wiki/Scientology), purports to treat a hypothetical [reactive mind](/wiki/Reactive_mind). There is no scientific evidence for the existence of an actual reactive mind, [[606]](#cite_note-608)apart from [Narconon](/wiki/Narconon)and [Purification Rundown](/wiki/Purification_Rundown)are Scientology programs that purport to clean the human body of toxins and drugs respectively. Their method consists of very long saunas over many days, extremely large (possibly toxic) doses of vitamins including [niacin](/wiki/Niacin_(substance)), and Scientology 'training routines', sometimes including attempts at [telekenesis](/wiki/Telekenesis). The programs have have dismissed Narconon's educational programme as containing "factual errors in basic concepts such as physical and mental effects, addiction and even spelling". [[625]](#cite_note-627) [[626]](#cite_note-628) [[627]](#cite_note-629) Idiosyncratic ideas The following concepts have only a very small number of proponents, yet have become notable: [Aquatic ape hypothesis](/wiki/Aquatic_ape_hypothesis)- the idea that certain ancestors of modern humans were more aquatic than other great apes and even many modern humans and, as such, were habitual waders, swimmers and divers. The science of psychoanalysis is the bedrock of psychodynamic understanding and forms the fundamental theoretical frame of reference for a variety of forms of therapeutic intervention, embracing not only psychoanalysis itself but also various forms of psychoanalytically oriented psychotherapy and related forms of [[494]](#cite_note-494) [^](#cite_ref-497) an important [paradigm](/wiki/Paradigm)organizing the way many psychiatrists think about patients and treatment. However, its limitations are more widely recognized and it is assumed that many important advances in the future will come from other areas, particularly biologic psychiatry. As yet unresolved is the appropriate role of psychoanalytic thinking in organizing the treatment of patients and the training of psychiatrists after that biologic revolution has born fruit. Will treatments aimed at biologic defects or abnormalities become technical steps in a program organized in a psychoanalytic framework? Will psychoanalysis serve to explain and guide supportive intervention for individuals whose lives are deformed by biologic defect and therapeutic interventions, much as it now does for patients with chronic physical illness, with the psychoanalyst on the psychiatric dialysis program? Or will we look back on the role of psychoanalysis in the treatment of the seriously mentally ill as the last and most scientifically enlightened phase of the humanistic tradition in psychiatry, a tradition that became extinct when advances in biology allowed us to cure those we had so long only comforted?" Error #2: He notes that the cyanide residue from one gas chamber wall is less than the residue from a wall inside a known delousing chamber.
